headline: Over 7 Million Vehicles Could Face The Brunt Of Trump's Auto Tariffs: 'This Could Drive...The Auto industry Into Recession'
summary: The U.S. auto industry is on the brink of a significant shakeup as a 25% tariff on imported vehicles looms, according to an industry expert. What Happened: Phil LeBeau, CNBC’s auto and airline industry expert, recently shed light on the potential consequences of a 25% tariff introduced by President Donald Trump on imported vehicles. With 7.38 million imported vehicles sold in the U.S. last year, the magnitude of the market that could be affected by such tariffs is substantial. Trending: Inspired

headline: Musk says a great wrong is being done to Tesla staff, customers -Fox News
summary: Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk said on Wednesday that a great wrong was being done to Tesla employees and customers when asked on Fox News' "Special Report with Bret Baier" about incidents at dealerships that include arson attacks. Tesla has become a target of activists opposed to the political agenda of President Donald Trump and the role of his adviser, Musk, who is leading a drive to slash the federal payroll through the Department of Government Efficiency. (This story has been corrected to fix Bret Baier's name in paragraph 1)

headline: Suspect Arrested for Firebombing Teslas in Las Vegas
summary: Las Vegas police announced the arrest of a person accused of shooting at and throwing Molotov cocktails on multiple Tesla cars.  The Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department arrested a suspect officials say firebombed five vehicles at a  Tesla  sales center last week.  Authorities said Thursday that  Paul Kim,  36 years old, shot at the vehicles and tossed Molotov cocktails at them, extensively damaging the cars.

headline: Tesla’s Stock Finishes the Day Higher, Following Auto Tariff News
summary: Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk says the electric-car maker won't be “unscathed” by President Trump’s 25% auto tariffs.  Tesla’s stock climbed 0.4% Thursday, while shares in GM, Ford and Jeep-maker Stellantis fell as investors digested the news of the new import duties on foreign-made cars that go into effect next week.  “To be clear, this will affect the price of parts in Tesla cars that come from other countries,” Musk wrote on his social-media platform X. “The cost impact is not trivial.”

headline: Deutsche Bank sees auto tariffs as more than negotiation tactic
summary: On Wednesday, the Trump administration confirmed a sweeping 25% tariff on all imported completed vehicles and certain auto parts not made in the United States, effective April 2, 2025.  This move is seen by Deutsche Bank as a permanent policy aimed at incentivizing the reshoring of automotive production to the US, rather than a temporary negotiating tactic.  The analyst then offered an overview of the impact on the auto industry, projecting Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) and Ford Motor Company (NYSE:F) as the least impacted among original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) due to their significant US assembly operations.

raw.headline: Deutsche Bank sees auto tariffs as more than negotiation tactic
raw.summary: On Wednesday, the Trump administration confirmed a sweeping 25% tariff on all imported completed vehicles and certain auto parts not made in the United States, effective April 2, 2025.  This move is seen by Deutsche Bank as a permanent policy aimed at incentivizing the reshoring of automotive production to the US, rather than a temporary negotiating tactic.  The analyst then offered an overview of the impact on the auto industry, projecting Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) and Ford Motor Company (NYSE:F) as the least impacted among original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) due to their significant US assembly operations.

headline: Tesla’s Stock Up, Following Auto Tariff News
summary: Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk says the electric-car maker won't be “unscathed” by President Trump’s 25% auto tariffs.  Tesla’s stock climbed more than 4% in morning trading Thursday, while shares in GM, Ford and Jeep-maker Stellantis fell as investors digested the news of the new import duties on foreign-made cars that go into effect next week.  “To be clear, this will affect the price of parts in Tesla cars that come from other countries,” Musk wrote on his social-media platform X. “The cost impact is not trivial.”

headline: Auto stocks feel the impact of Trump's latest tariff: Market Minute
summary: Both European and American automakers are seeing their shares take a hit from President Trump's decision to put a 25% levy on vehicles and some auto parts imported into the US. There are a couple of auto stocks moving higher though. Both Tesla and Rivian are trading higher given how much of their production is in the United States. Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: Trump’s Auto Tariffs: Which Companies Win and Lose?
summary: After weeks of speculation, the auto tariffs announced by President Trump on Wednesday ended up being almost a worst-case scenario for carmakers.  The U.S. president previously granted an exemption to his tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada for goods complying with free-trade-area rules.  The result: Ford and GM could face a 30% hit to their operating profit this year even if they increase prices and adjust sourcing, according to Bernstein.

raw.headline: Trump’s Auto Tariffs: Which Companies Win and Lose?
raw.summary: After weeks of speculation, the auto tariffs announced by President Trump on Wednesday ended up being almost a worst-case scenario for carmakers.  The U.S. president previously granted an exemption to his tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada for goods complying with free-trade-area rules.  The result: Ford and GM could face a 30% hit to their operating profit this year even if they increase prices and adjust sourcing, according to Bernstein.

headline: Trump's auto tariffs will hit many companies, but Elon Musk's Tesla less so
summary: (Reuters) -As the global auto world reeled from the potential fallout of Donald Trump's new auto tariffs, one name stood out as less affected than others - electric-vehicle maker Tesla.  The Texas-based company's shares were the rare automotive stock to trade in the green in U.S. action, as analysts said Tesla's supply chain and financial performance may not be affected by the wide-ranging levies that will affect global shipments of both cars and car parts to the United States, mainly due to the company's largely domestic production.  Still, that relief in the United States, where Musk has become one of President Trump's primary advisers, tasked with swiftly cutting federal spending, may not improve the brand's reputation worldwide.

Still, that relief in the United States, where Musk has become one of President Trump's primary advisers, tasked with swiftly cutting federal spending, may not improve the brand's reputation worldwide.

headline: Auto tariffs, trade talks, stock futures: 3 Things
summary: Morning Brief hosts Brad Smith and Madison Mills highlight three stories to watch for. President Trump's push for a 25% tariff on autos is sending shockwaves through the European and American auto industries, with European stocks falling and automakers like Mercedes-Benz (MBGYY) facing potential major losses. American car stocks are mixed today, with General Motors (GM) and Ford (FORD) lower while Tesla (TSLA) trades higher. Additionally, President Trump threatens larger tariffs on the EU and Canada, and US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) point to a lower open as investors digest the news of Trump's tariffs. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

The 25% tariffs on cars and light trucks imported into the U.S. will start on April 2, while tariffs on auto parts will take effect from May 3.

headline: Investors react as Trump auto tariffs rattle markets
summary: Europe was braced to sell with the euro at three-week lows and German DAX futures down 0.8%. KYLE RODDA, SENIOR FINANCIAL MARKET ANALYST, CAPITAL.COM, MELBOURNE "There are a lot of layers here. However, I think the big concern is that not only will these tariffs be disruptive and economically harmful, but it indicates that the Trump administration's shake-up of global trade won't necessarily end with next week's April 2nd announcement of reciprocal tariffs, as previously hoped.
